tagDescription: to Lady Selkirk.(French.) Regarding Red River Mission.
to Colvile. Portuguese Government making arrangements to engage soldiers and settlers for Brasil. Suggests lowering passage money to Red River.
to de May. (French.)
to Colvile. Acknowledges the correctness of his accounts.All matters settled to his satisfaction.Has no further claims on Lord Selkirk's estate nor upon the Hudson's Bay Company.
to Colvile. Informing him that he is leaving with 170 persons of all ages. Hopes to be in Rotterdam on 21 or 22 May.
to Colvile. 169 passengers taken. £1267 paid. Gives general report. Asks speedy reply at Dort.

to Colvile. Will comply will instructions, sending 250,persons. Distrust in Germany and Switzerland caused by emigrants returned from the United-States now awaiting favourable reports from Red River settlers.
List of Books belonging to the Settlement.
to Colvile. Gives favourable report.Portuguese Government unsuccessful.
to de May.(Copy.) Gerard Mauritz to undertake business with Dutch Governement relating to embarcation of settlers at Rotterdam.
to W.Laidlaw.(Copy.) Regarding his claim for salary. Gives him instructions as to farm and informs him of new arrangements qith the North West Company.
to Colvile. Blames Colonel Dickson for trouble among the Indians.Complaints made against Dickson and Laidlaw.
to de May. Forwards new Power of Attorney. Terms with Mr. de Salis.
to Colvile. Would purchase majority of shares in Hudson's Bay Company.
to Colvile. Forwards indent for the ensuing year. Inventory of goods on hand,and general report.
to Alex.McDonell.Authorizing him to collect any debts due to Lord Selkirk's Estate.
to A.L.Prevost. Reply to his letter of enquiry regarding settlers intended for Red River.
to de May. (Copy.) His letter of 1 February received.Instructions on need of settlers.
to Colvile. Expresses anxiety at not hearing from him. Rumoured loss of ship Wellington.
to A. Bulger. Replies to questions as to his reasons for leaving the Settlement.
to Colvile. Sale of land at Grand River to William Smith for his judgment.
John McNab.Extract from will showing indebtedness to Lord Selkirk.
Carpenters tools,Donald McDonald,carpenter.Gardeners tools,John Mitchell,gardener.
(4) to Matthey. Requests him to remain at the Settlement. Will be provided for from the stores.
to G.Garden. Letter and packet received. Alex. McDonell to go out in March. New Roman Catholic Missionary to relieve Provencher,accompanied by a young man.
to Colvile. Letter of 10th May received.Will forward list of people with charges against them.
to Colvile. Relating to Lord Selkirk's affairs in Upper Canada.Daniel McKenzie constantly drunk and unfit for business.
to de May. Refers to young man mentioned in d'Orsennens letter. Cost of passage. (French.)
to Alex.McDonell. (Copy.) Regarding his appointment and salary.
to de May. Letters referred to were sent by Captain Matthey.Has had a report from McDonell on arrival of the Swiss people.
to Colvile. Reports his journey and arrival. Considers Swiss settlers should obtain supplies in England.Land grants for Colony servants.
to Colvile. Informing him of the progress in establishing the Buffalo Wool Company.Difficulty in obtaining supplies. Logan and Laidlaw desire to become partners.Has drawn for Captain Matthey's £200.
to de May. (Copy.) Refers to his account and commission.
to de May. Terms offered.
to Colville. Regarding a township at Red River and his personal. Was answered in the negative in October,but suggests another arrangement.
to de May. Lord Selkirk's death.Swiss settlers.
to Colvile. Further report on Swiss settlers for Red River with particulars of their engagement.
Observations on Colonel Bossit's paper.(Copy.) On the appointment of a Governor of the Assiniboia Territory.
to Colvile. Letters from Baden asking same terms for workhouse people as settlers from Berne.
to Selkirk. Regarding his cousin,David Henning,just appointed parish minister.
to de May. Will forward duplicates of letters of 10 and 15 June if not received.
to Colvile. Requests quick despatch of letters for settlers' families in Switzerland.
to Colvile. Letter of 28 May received. Justifies his prospectus. Wishes to engage settlers for the next year.
to Colvile. Forwards letter from T.Clarke relating to lands seized for  judgment.
to Colvile. (Confidential.) Referring to wintering partners. Governor Williams arrest of Murray,one of the North West Company's clerks.Arrest of Colin Robertson.
to A.Bulgor. Replies to his examination as to reasons for leaving the Settlement.
(5) to Matthey. Isgratified that his conduct keeps Red River Settlement quiet.
Buffalo Wool Company to James Bird. (Copy.) Complains of shortage of buffalo hides.
Statement of provisions received and expended since June,1821.
List of North West Company people at Grand River, 1820.
to Selkirk. Purchase of cattle for Red River.
to Colvile. Is on his way to Paris.
to d'Orsennens. Letters received.No Swiss settlers going to Red River this season.No,possibility of transferring settlers from Brazil to Red River.

to Alex. McDonell. Arrangements completed with the North West Company for trade. Hudson's Bay Company to conduct trade of country,North West partners to receive a certain share.Settlers from Switzerland to arrive during season.Preparations to be made to receive them.

to Bulger. Regarding the hardships of the settlers. Questions as to their righs for purchasing furs and provisions where they please?Law and magistrates promised,also circulation of notes,but not carried out.Deeds for land promised but not given.
to Executors of the late Lord Selkirk. Long memorial relating to his son and payment of money.
to de May. Is displeased with alterations made in instructions.Present state of settlement very favourable.
to de May.(French.) Relating to Rhine navigation dues.
to Colvile. Has sent his son home,and hopes his family may be granted a passage with him on his return.Possibility of settlers fromGuernsey.
to Dousman.(Copy.) Receipt for cattle brought to the Settlement,$10,080.
to Colvile. Enclosing letter for Captain d'Orsennens' brother proposing reduction of amount of passage money or part paid down.
to Louis Minot. Agreement with Mr.Dousman for a supply of tobacco to be delivered in September,1823
to de May. Authorize arrangement for people from the workhouse to go as settlers.Free land grants.
to Colvile. Regarding to the difficulties raised by Dutch Governement to passage of settlers through Holland. Encloses Dutch Ambassador's letter. Enclosures:-
to Matthey.(Copy.) Letter of 28 January received.No objection to giving certificate for lands.Further remarks on his claims.
to de May.(Copy.) A ship for the settlers to be chartered. Encouragement may be givien Mr.Droz,Dr. Hoerner's family and the veterinary.
to de May. (Copy.) No criminals to be included among people from the workhouse. Free passage and return for Government inspector.

to Colvile. Claiming remuneration from Hudson's Bay Company for services. Forwards barometer and thermometer readings. Crops again ruined by locusts. Attempts made to domesticate the buffalo. Settlers complain of high prices.
Deposition of William Todd,dated May 21st. Rescue of prisoners at Grand Rapids.
to Colvile. Referring to Scotch bonnets and forage caps to be sent out. Laidlaw's demand for a salary.
to Colvile. Referring to wintering partners of the North West and Hudson's Bay Company.Gives extracts from Moffat's letter to Dr.McLaughlin.
Settlers lands to be marked but not enclosed.
to Colvile. Enclosing letter from R.Dickson to himself. Settlers alarmed,but quiet again.Suggests form of government necessary for welfare of the Settement.
to Colvile. Many Swiss settlers leaving for the Unites States as no transport was sent to Red River this year. Urges the necessity for engaging people in good time.
to Colvile. Further information about wintering partners.Simpson's views regarding Governor Williams. Observations on the Settlement; land grants to settlers. Proposed settlement by Grant Forrest.
to Alex. McDonell. Instructions regarding land for John Pritchard for use of Buffalo Wool Company's factory.
de Meuron settlers to Selkirk. Memorandum on letters from Settlers.Articles furnished by Selkirk.No distinction made between settlers.
(1) to G.Simpson.Trouble between the Sioux and Saulteaux Indians averted.Captain Matthey gone to Montreal and England;complaints against his actions, none regret his leaving.
Extracts from correspondence relative to Red River. (Copies.)
to -----. General instructions regarding the Settlement in view of Lord Selkirk's death.

to Matthey. Enquires what other matters remain to be settled by estate. Claims against Hudson's Bay Company separate; the Governor and Committee have directed £200 be paid to him in compensation for services.
Memorandum of Mr.Roletes account with Red River Settlement.
to de May.(Copy.) General instructions regarding settlers. Refers to the complaint from F.Riser. Not to raise capitation tax from people.
Maitland.Garde & Company. Referring to Captain Matthey and general accounts.
German translation of Colvile's letter to the de Meurons. A copy delivered to them.
to de May. (Copy.) Circumstances prevent his sanctioning de Salis' journey to Red River.
to Colvile. Report on Swiss settlers;too late this season.Will prepare flat boats for transportation. Terms for leases to be same as in French seigneuries in Canada.
Tinsmith tools.Thomas Fletcher.
Magazine and Kitchen utensils,Hugh Munro.
Memorandum for the guidance of Alex. McDonell as agent for the Executors of Lord Selkirk at Red River.
Has received favourable reply from Baden Government.
(2) to Matthey. Looks to him for assistance. Expexts to transport 200 Swiss settlers arriving from Rotterdam to the Colony.
(3) to Governor Williams. Writes in confidence of against Governor McDonell and the people's dislike and distrust of him.
to de May. Letter received.Clergyman not necessary for first settlers. No further emigrants to be engaged on same terms.
An Abstract of Fahrenheit's thermometer and barometer at Red River.
Statement of stock in hand,June 1, amounting to £2424-15-0.
to Colvile. Report of his work and Colony matters for the past year. Has performed 29 Marriages;baptisms 153. Building of church and manse not yet attempted. Is building schoolhouse.
Is pleased with Mr. de Huser;considers him a great acquisition.
to Colvile. Letter of 28 October received. Urges necessity of using de Hauser's report at once.
Stock on hand,4 March.Statement.
to Gale. Regarding wintering partners. Offer from E.Ellice to purchase Lord Selkirk's stock; evidently acting for North West Company.
to Lady Selkirk. Enclosing estate accounts. Reports on the farms.
to Colvile. Regarding payment of Laidlaw's drafts. Unreasonable demands made by Missionaries.Account received from Mr.Wood of York.
to de May. Considers the Swiss settlers sent to Red River ill chosen. The commission he has retained too large.
to de may. Requests a list of persons going to Red River.Not to exceed 200 for the present year.Will arrange security required by Dutch Government.
to Ermatinger. Letter of 19 July received. Dickson's supplies. Asks for list of supplies at the Sault.
to Gerard Mauritz. Arrangements for transit of passengers on the ship Lord Wellington,Captain Furbister. Provisions to be shipped.
to Colvile. Further offer for shares.
Enclsoure:- Contract between R.de May and Monsieur Francois Zuricher.
List of goods supplied Hudson's Bay Company.
(3) to Matthey. Thanks him for offer of services.
to T.Clarke. Referring to land sold for judgments.
John McNab. Claims for services to Lord Selkirk and the Hudson's Bay Company.
to Colvile. Letters received. Wishes to send 400 settlers; gives reasons. Many more will follow,all of good type.
to Colvile. Offer of Berne Government if 40 persons are taken from workhouse.Reasons for agreeing.
to de May. Forwards letters from Red River. Refuses to sanction de Salis going to Red River. Considers Mr.de Hauser's description of the country will prove sufficient.
to Colvile. Informing him of debts contracted in supplying settlers.Refers to Mr.Halkett for justification of his conduct.
to Colvile. Informing him of events at Red River since his arrival there in August,1818.Regrets the mismanagement of the Colony.Trouble and disturbances among the Indians.
Repudiating charges against himself.More favourable report of emigrants.Remarks about de Salis. Wishes to send Mr.de Huser as well to enlist settlers.
Continuation of a document given to de May on the favourable conditions in Red River Settlement.
to Colvile. Letter of 10 April received; translated and read to the people.
to Colvile. Guarantee asked by Baden Government before recruiting commences.
to Colvile. Reports that 170 cattle have reached Red River,Crops excellent.Demands of Roman Catholic clergy unreasonable.Hopes to return next summer.
Governors of Appenzell. (German.) Presumably regarding the promise of assistance in sending out settlers referred to in de May's letter.
Buffalo Wool Company to Thomas Thomas and James Bird. Regarding the agreement with the Hudson's Bay Co. for buffalo hides.
to Gale. On the settlement of Miles McDonell's accounts.
to Colvile. Translator's error using word "enclosed".Suggests inscription for stones marking lots.
to Miles McDonell. Referring him to G.Gale for settlement of his account,dated 5 December,1818.
to Colvile. Will comply with instructions. Could obtain many young women; but they have not the passage money.Requirements Dutch Government regarding passage and embarking.
to Gale. Regarding the settlement of his account.
Enclosed:- to Captain Bulger. Increasing his salary.
to Colvile. Dr.McLaughlin and Bethune arrive from interior on their way to England. Offer to trade with Hudson's Bay Company when lease with North West Company expires in 1822.
Return of settlers,cattle and seed in the spring of 1822.
to Colvile. Swiss Government favours emigration.Matters of transport. Feeding of settlers en route to Rotterdam. Accounts and expenses.
to J.Halkett. Regarding his land in the Assiniboia district.
(5) to George Simpson. Settlement in need of a Governor.Pritchard busy with his Buffalo Wool Company. Many new settlers could be accommodated. Many squabbles in Settlement.
(4) to Governor Williams. Considers the Catholic people bigoted.
to R.Dickson. Copy of accounts and Receipts.
to Colvile. Leaves for Basle. No people going from Neufchatel.About 180 settlers will sail.
to Colvile. Defends his selection of settlers. Terms of his agreement; commission on sums paid for passages.
to Colvile. Regarding lands seized for judgment. Lord Srlkirk's money affairs.
to Colvile.(French.) Requesting a grant of land for the Catholic church and Mission at Pembina.
to de May. Considers reduction in passage money impossible. Ship chartered. May engage schollmaster; free passage in unmarried man.McDonell notified to make all necessary arrangements.
to Colvile. Further favourable report on progess.Ship to sail on the 30 May.

to Lady Selkirk. Informing her the trials in Court of Common Pleas postponed. Hearing before Privy Council.Particulars required as to how the North West Company's Red Book was obtained. Death of McNab and his wife.
to Colvile. Letters from Red River not received. Ill effects of delay.
List of boats belonging to the Settlement.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo.(Copy.) Unavoidably detained. Has carried out Lord Selkirk's instructions. Extra expense caused by delay.
to Colvile. Letter of 25 June received.Had no intention of offending.Will submit to his decision.
to Colvile. Complains bitterly of his position.Proposes conditions for  remaining,otherwise engagement terminates in July 1823. Encloses a letter from J. Halkett in support of his claim.

to Colvile. Report on the Swiss Settlers People very poor. 10 of the girls married already to the de Meurons. Buffalo very plentiful. 100 carts left Pembina to bring in meat.Has heard that the drove of 284 head of cattle died from lack of food,but a new lot are on the way from the vicinity of St.Louis.Presents made to Indians under threats from Colonel Dickson.Has dismissed Laidlaw who has gone to the United States.Regrets loss of gunboat in a strm on Lake Winnipeg in October.
to Colvile. General report on state of colony. Crops good.
to G.Garden.(Copy.) Announces Lord Selkirk's death.Names Stewart,Gale and O'Sullivan as counsel to be retained as executors.
Opinion of Council on points submitted to them regarding the determination of certain Swiss settlers about to leave the Red River Colony and their transactions with Augustin Nolin.
to Selkirk.General abstract of estate accounts.
to Colvile. Requests advance of £4.
to W.Williams. Explaining the difficulties attending the establishment of the buffalo wool industry.
to John Todd. Receipt for 248 pieces of goods by Hudson's Bay Company.
to Colvile. Reports of his efforts to secure next year's transport.of settlers.
to Colvile. Observations on the arrangements concluded between the Hudson's Bay and North West Company concluded at London. Considers it all in favour of McGillivray and Ellice.
to J.Pritchard. Regarding buffalo hides for his Company.
(1) to Matthey. (Copy.) Applies for assistance from de Meuron regiment to keep the peace.

to de May. Fears from what he has heard that the prospectus published has been too favourable on certain points; not having seen it cannot assume any blame. Settlers feel they have been misled.Will send out a mill-wright,blacksmith and land surveyor in the summer.Also to send instructions for administration of justice and enrolling a portion of the settlers for their own defence.
Houses,buildings,supplies and boats at Fort Douglas.

to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo.(Copy.) General report of movements. Furnished with a pass by General Bryde. An American Sergeant and private killed by the Indians at Rock River Fort.Conditions at the Red River Settlement.
to Colvile. Regrets Lord Selkirk's decision. Reasons for making offer.
to de May. Refused to be drawn into a controversy.Reasons for proceeding slowly.Report of Settlement necessary before sending more settlers.
to Adam D.Stewart. Replying to his 30 January offering to take 250 head of cattle to Red River.
to Colvile. Regrets delay in hearing;causes bad impression on the people. Complaints made against McDonell's treatment of the Swiss settlers.
to de May.Letters of 5 and 10 May received. Instructions given to Gerard Mauritz for supplies.List of persons to be sent to Alex.McDonell of Red River.

to Lady Selkirk. Prosecutions against Halkett abandoned. Vandersluys dismissed by North West Company. Assembly determined to keep Lower Provinces for French Canadians only. Union of the provinces and inevitable reparation foreseen.
to de may. Regrets false reports received by intending settlers. No alterations in terms possible.
to Colvile. Will comply with instructions for settlers on their voyage.
to Colvile. Unfavourable report of first clergyman engaged,also of agent employed.General report of settlers. Would appreciate Matthey's assistance.
to de May. (Copy.) Arrangements made with the Dutch Government for proper securities. Ship of 410 tons chartered.Forwards his letter from Rizer and his reply.
to Colvile. Remarks on Mr. de Salis' desire to got to Red River.
to Colvile. Official enquiries regarding settlers for Red River. Enclosure:
to Colvile. Enclosing McDonell's letter with observations upon the proprierty of it.
(6) to Alex. Kennedy. On mismanagement of the Settlement.Considers the Buffalo Wool Company will succeed.
List of blacksmith tools in use,signed by David Tully,blacksmith.
to Colvile. Observations as to condition of the Red River Colony.His own conduct. Encloses copy of correspondence.
Dutch Minister to de May.(French.) Regarding Swiss emigrants passing through Holland.
to John McDonell. Regarding his brother Miles claim against Lord Selkirk's estate.
to de May. Will allow £50 to sub-agents. Asks names of people from Baden workhouse.
to Colvile. Further request from de Salis to proceed to Red River.Promises of help from local authorities if his report is good.
to Colvile. Regrets Lord Selkirk's death. Further report on Swiss settlers.
to J.Berens.(Immediate.) Has reasons to fear renewal of Hostilities between the Hudson's Bay and North West Company. Instructions required.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo. Advising of a Bill granted Nolin for £100.

to Alex. McDonell.(Copy.) Instructions in regard to Laidlaw's salary. Final settlemnt made with North West company. Instructions regarding packages. The Encyclopedia Francaise,27 or 28 volumes, to be returned to Lady Selkirk.
to G.Mauritz. Expects papers and accounts left by Captain de May.
Copy of a paper found in the office of the Red River Colony, purporting to be an account of provisions issued by Mr.Fletcher to the Swiss settlers during the winter 1821-22.
to G.Garden.(Copy.) Reporting the arrival of McDonell and Simpson.Advances made on Dickson's bill.Cattle from St.Louis. Grasshoppers again in evidence.
Copy of letters to de May signed by 70 persons. (French.)
Endorsed: We cannot attend to his promise of land to Colonel Leavenworth.
to Colvile. Has presented 2000 acres of his land to Colonel Leavenworth,U.S.A., at Turtle River for American farmers.War among the Sault and Sauteaux Indians.
to Colvile. Further report on enlistment of settlers.

to Colvile. Distribution of cattle among the settlers.McDonell's claim to land. Stoves required.Supply of fuel a serious question in the Colony. Consumption of wood enormous; is convinced there will be none within ten miles of the colony in five years.Provisions sent out very poor.Settlers complain of Simpson's regulations against buying provisions and skins from the indians.Remarks on the Government of the Colony.List of bills annexed.
to de May. Regarding their agreement and next year's transport.

to Colviel. The two young men mentioned before are Joseph Mundweiler and Benedict Schaub. Will follow directions as to baggage.Has ascertained that the man who wrote against him is Rizer,of Renan; and pretends to have received an answer.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo. Referring to his expenses; his drafts for balance of the men's wages. Praises Captain Matthey's ability.

to Colvile. Recommendations made to Mr.Halkett. Miss Boden to open a girl's school at Red River. Refers to waste and neglect of property and suggests means to remedy it. Price of goods?Will visit Athabasca,Peace River,Lesser Slave Lake and the upper posts of the Saskatchewan during the winter in an effort to check abuses.
and others to Colvile, and Halkett. (French.) Petition and representation against Alex.McDonell. 84 names.
to Alex.McDonell. (French.) Depositions signed and ubmitted by 14 of the settlers.
to de May. Stating his reasons for the smaller number of settlers.
to W.Williams. Expresses thanks of the Buffalo Wool Company for his assistance.Has manufactured wool at Pembina. Now engaged in erection of buildings. Will send sample of leather.
(C) to Halkett. Second request for an interview.
(B) to Halkett. Requesting interview on subject of his book,published in London,in which conspicuous use is made of his name.
to Lady Selkirk. Satisfied with arrangement between the companies. General report of her friends.
to Colvile. Introducing Captain d'Orsennens who returns to Switzerland.Report received from Mr.Garry on the arrangements between the Hudson's Bay and North West Companies.
to Gale. Proposals from Colonel Pearce to bring New England settlers to Red River. Price of lots. Amount of Dickson's land. Gives a sketch of the Grand Fauche,corrected by Colvile.
to Colvile. Affidavit for Alex.McBeath's pension. Has drawn bills for salary due Donald McDermott, James Brown and John Moran.
to de May. Letter received from the Swiss Consul. Advises him to take no notice of Rizer. Hopes people will be ready to embark at Rotterdam by 20 May.

to Colvile. Reports on affairs at the Colony.Journeyed from York to Red River via the various posts.Indians offended by change in trade arrangements. Swiss settlers arrival in November; many suffered during the winter from lack of food.Buffalo scarce,driven away by the Indians. Remarks on the people in charge of the posts.Remarks on the Rev. Mr.West's activities. Regulations for land grants to retired servants not defined;awaits instructions.Suggests a steamboat for use in carrying goods from York in the spring.Fort Douglas progressing.Will move into the North West Company buildings in the fall.Proposes calling it Fort Garry to commemorate Mr.Garry's visit No mill erected. Cuthbert Grant much respected by the Indians and settlers. Gives various items of gossip.
to de May.(Copy.) Lord Selkirk's executors cannot agree to his remaining another year at Red River. Gives reasons for this decision.
to Colviel. Reports a meeting held at Neufchatel and promises made by alleged agent for setttlers. Discouraging accounts of Red River said to have been received.
to de May.(French.) On letter received from Mr.Colvile.
to de May. Terms,conditions and prospects for Red River settlers.
to Colvile. Report on Swiss settlers.
to Thomas Clarke. Informing him of Lord Selkirk's death on the 8th instant at Pau. Refers to judgments obtained by Smith and McKenzie against his Lordship.
to Matthey. Letter of 23 December received. Remarks on his own position as e xecutor and affairs at Red River.Refers to his claim on the Hudson's Bay Company for services.
to de May. (Copy.) Mr de Hauser returned from Red River. Report not yet made. Definite instructions later.
to Colvile. Swiss government declined to give any public sanction to proposals, but put no restraint on people engaging.
to Colvile. Letter of 15 August received and forwarded.Is sure it will prove satisfactory to the Baden Government.Germany favourable to scheme.
to Gale. Alex. McDonell to proceed to Red River in Hudson's Bay canoes.Simpson to take charge should McDonell be detained.Lands offered to Swiss settlers.Matthey to settle on his land.
to de May. Regarding the commission due him. Quality of settlers from Switzerland.
to Colvile. Referring to cattle contract. Indians stealing horses. Complains of a man named Alley causing trouble in the colony and to himself.
to Colvile. Further request for remuneration.
to T.Clarke. Long account of Lord Selkirk's affairs in Upper Canada. Lands, debtors,with documents. Extract from John McNab'swill and claim for services rendered.
to de May. Informing him of the cost of passages,£20 per head.
Instructions to McDonell for measuring of lands for Captain Matthey and Colonel Dickson. (Copy.)
to Colvile. Reports arrival of Company boats. Requests that his wife and family may come next summer. Crops are excellent.
to G.Garden. Regarding Miles McDonell's account.Will settle with Dickson,Dowsman for Cattle.Terms of payment.
to Laidlaw. Regarding his son's salary.
to de May. Letter forwarded to F.Auguste Pethond,Renan,for discontented people.
to Colvile. Report on conference with Simon McGillivray regarding an arrangement between the Hudson's Bay Company and the North West Company.
(7) to George Simpson. Replying to his of 24 June. Matthey away. All quiet in the Settlement.Has been instructed to meet the ships and bring the Settlers up.
to G.Mauritz. Forwards letter for de May. Instructions for advance to P.Reynberger.
to de may. Changes necessary in cases of Swiss clergymen and schoolmasters. Arrangements for housing new settlers. Must sign agreement as agent.
Building,stock,supplies at the Farm.
to Colvile. Referring to Lord Selkirk's Upper Canada lands seize by Smith and McKenzie's judgments.
to Colvile. Had come down to meet the new settlers who left on the 1September. Complaints of the de Meurons about Captain Matthey heard by Mr.Garry.General account of the Settlement and Indians.
to G.Mauritz. Referring to invoice for flour intended for Hudson's Bay Company.Proposed remuneration for himself.
to Colvile. Regarding the Buffalo Wool Company.Captain Matthey leaving for England. Scarcity of provisions. High prices prevail.
to de May. With promise of £100 to person chosen to accompany Swiss settlers to Red River,and return to report to the Berne Government. Memo.
to de May. Refusing reduction of passage money.

to Colvile. Letters received.Letters from Colonel Leavenworth,U.S.A. Friendly intercourse established between Red River and U.S.A. Settlement grieved at Selkirk's death.Purchase of cattle for Red River.Expenses incurred.
to Alex. McDonell. Referring to the grant of land to the Catholic Mission.
to Miles McDonell.(Copy.) Engaging him to manage the Red River Colony; terms, land grant and salary.

to Colvile. Acknowledges letters received.Arrival of Nicholas Garry and favourable account of him; unfavourable of McDonell,Cuddie and others. Is to have charge of the Northern Department; Mr.Williams of the Southern. Swiss settlers arrived in good health; Mr.Todd very attentive to them.Grasshoppers very destructive.Change of Governor necessary for good of Colony.Rewards on Buffalo Wool Co. McGillivray continues hostile to the Settlement.Deplores loss of 13 sheep by drowning. Colin Robertson anxious for chief Factorship of Ottawa River,qith quarters at Montreal. Considers Dr.Cuddie troublesome and worthless.

Meeting at Fort Daer for the protection of the Settlement.Alex.McDonell in the chair. Present: Reverends J John West,J.N.S.Dumoulin,des Troismaisons and Sauveur; Captain F.Matthey; R.Dickson,R.Logan,J.Pritchard,H.W. Cook,esquires; Alex.Cuddie.Surgeon; Lieut.Angus McDonald; Messrs.John Alley,Henry Eustace,James Monkman,Thomas Fletcher, Augustin Nolin,J.Baptiste Nolin and John Bruce. Resolutions adopted.
to de May. Free passages to leader to settlers; encouragement to others.
to de May. No emigrants to go out this year. Money matters arranged with de Hauser.
to Colvile. General account of progress of the Colony.
to Colvile. Has engaged Mr. de Salis to take charge of settlers. To go to Red River and return with a report on it. Clergyman engaged.
Supplies remaining in spring,1822.
to Clarke. Bills paid on his account for £250.Payment made on Smith and McKenzie's judgments.Sale of lands.
to Colvile. Enclosing letters received from persons at the meeting referred to.Protest against letter sent to intending settlers by Colvile. Enclosure:-
Account of stock on land at Red River.
to J.Halkett. Forwards letter from James Woods on matters of interest to Executors and Government paptents for lands granted.
to Colvile. General report of Settlement affairs. No buffalo skins this year for factory. Swis settlers have not arrived. Mill stones found in the vicinity,very fine; no need to send any others.

to Colvile. Letter of 9 March received Good results from Mr. Halkett's visit.Failure of the buffalo may have good results by inducing the people to attend to their agricultural pursuits. Halfbreeds causing trouble a very worthless lot of people.Reports on affairs and people at the Settlement. The Nelson River track is good and shorter by three weeks to York.
to Lady Selkirk. Gives an a ccount of the quarrel between Halkett and Vandersluys. Letters enclosed. Enclosures:-
(2) to Alex.McDonell. Replying to his letter. Considers his conduct slack and much to blame for lack of provisions.Illicit trade in furs being carried on.
to Colvile. Enclosing a second letter from meeting of intending settlers; all falsehoods. Enclosures:-
to R.Dickson. Referring to his contract with Dowsman for cattle; his half ownership. Exceeding Lord Selkirk's instructions.
______to Selkirk. Same subject as above.
to Colvile. Passage money for settlers going out in 1822.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo. Regarding his claim against Lord Selkirk's estate. Encloses copy of his Lordship's letter appointing him to charge of the Settlement. Explains his services.
to G.Garden. Letter of 29 January received. Bills accepted on Lord Selkirk's account. Settlement with Miles McDonell.
to Colvile. Letter of 4 January received. Considers himself entitled to more liberal consideration. Asks for legal possession of his land.
to Ellice. Unable to reply to his request for shares until Lord Selkirk is heard from.
to Maitland,Garden & Auldjo.(Copy.) Men going to Montreal for balance of wages.Laidlaw's expedition to Prairie du Chien successful. McDonald at head of Settlement.
to de May. Enclosing letter to Baden Minister referring to settlers.
Account of buildings and other properties.Valued at £4620.
to Arch.McDonald. Informing him of Selkirk's death. Arrangements for his partnership in Hudson's Bay Company.
to Selkirk. Request for salary for his son.
Articles of Agreement between Colonel Dickson and Michael Dowsman for forwarding cattle to Red River.
Account of goods sold since June.
to Colvile. Report on affairs at the Settlement.100 American men to settle at Pembina. Church amazes the natives.Letters lost qith canoes. Crops excellent.
to J.Pritchard. Letter received.Unable to assist in moving the bark mill.Has forwarded 77 seasoned hides from the Saskatchewan department.
to Colvile. Further remarks in regard to de Salis going to Red River.
Dutch Minister Plenipotentiary to de May. (French.) Condition for transport of foreign emigrants through Holland.
to Colvile. Anxious for employment for his son.Has taken shares in the Buffalo Wool Company.
to Laidlaw. Referring to his demand for salary.Loss of crops at Red River.

to J.Halkett.(Copy.) Rejoicing at prospect of his visit.Regrets the sufferings of the settlers from lack of food.Warns him of Colonel Dickson's character. Gives a general report of affairs in the Colony. Requests to inform him that Lieut.Hood and eight of the Arctic Expedition died from starvation attempting to cross from Copper Mine to Wager Bay.Captain Franklin expected daily.
to Colvile. Referring to his claims and salary; return of Hudson's Bay Commission.Statement of account.
to de May.(French.) Referring to another meeting of the emigrants for Red River at Renan.
to de May. Letter of 14 December received. McDonell not wholly to blame for conditions.Consent to de Salis going to Red River denied.
to de May. Unnecessary for de Salis to go to Red River; Hauser's report will be sufficient.
to Colvile.(Copy.) Explains attitude of Government.Conditions of emigration.Bresil vs Canada. Reason for reduction of passage money.Reference to workhouse emigrants. General report.
to Colvile. Has returned to Berne and commenced recruiting for next spring.
to de May. Men must agree to help in boat navigation from Hudson's Bay to Red River. Is anxious for news. Engagement of ships.Unfavourable news of Lord Selkirk's health.
to Colvile. Letters received. asks for further powers in enlisting settlers; hopes for 200.
to Colvile. Letters received.Alternative instructions only proposed for approval. Report on proceedings. Asks instructions.
to Colvile. Letter of 25 May received.Expenses inevitablei in such an undertaking. Hopes for future success.
to Colvile. Will comply with instructions contained in letter of 29 October regarding payments.
to Messrs. Charles and Samuel Fairbanks. Referring to land in Prince Edward Island.

to J.Pritchard. Statement of recent transactions.Describes the folly and stupidity of Alley who is in charge of the Settlement. Provisions scarce. Trouble between the Sioux and Saulteaux Indians at Fort Douglas. Fears for the safety of himself and family.
(A) to J.Halkett. Enquiring if he is the author of letters to Lord Bathurst and requesting a public retraction of assertions about himself.
to Colvile. Request information regarding purchase of shares.
to Colvile.(Copy. ) Account of Halkett's shooting of Vandersluys.
to Colvile. Giving an account of what has been done since his arrival. Full particulars in papers in Mr.Halkett's possession.
to Colvile. Reasons for a transport to go out next year with settlers.
to Messrs. Musick & Dickson.(Copy.) Referring to horses lost by death; does not consider Executors of Lord Selkirk's Estate responsible.

Representations from Red River Settlers to Colvile and Halkett,Executors to the Earl of Selkirk,in favour of Captain Matthey to command the troops who might be stationed at Red River. Signed by 55 persons.

List of officers and servants upon the establishment at Red River,with remarks on John Alley, Thomas Fletcher, Angus McDonald,Alex.Cuddie,Paul Reynberger, Donald McDonald,David Tully, John Mitchell,Alex.McDougall, High Munro,George McCree,James Fraser,and others.
to de May. Letters received. Instructions regarding settlers. Security to the Dutch Government arranged for.
to Colvile. No reply from Baden Government. Plenty of Swiss settlers. Protestant minister engaged. Requirements of Dutch Government for embarkation of Settlers.
to Alex. McDonell,(Copy.) Appointing him agent at Red River. Instructions.
Maitland, Garden & Auldjo to Colvile. Settlement accounts for 1816
to Colvile. Account Books forwarded.
to Colvile. Letters received.Reports every thing quiet at the Settlement.
to de May. Unless the emigrants can pay the £10 and are contented would have smaller number.
to Colvile. Favourable report from de Salis on securing settlers.Agreement with a young clergyman, Monsieur Francois Zuricher,of Berne.Land grants to settlers.
to Colvile. Forwards Miles McDonell's letter concerning his accounts.Gives information as to fresh warrants. Opinion as to arrangement between Hudson's Bay and North West Company.Lawsuits pending.
to Matthey. (Copy.) Letter of 12 January received. Arrangements to be made regarding his return to Red River,and his title to lands.
to Colvile. Continued bad weather,but favour able advance made down the Rhine. Requests advance on profits of 1823.
to Colvile. Has made some alterations in terms received.Suggestions as to transport and treatment of settlers.
to de May. Transit duties not likely to be remitted.Dr.Todd goes with ship in Medical capacity.
to J.Pritchard. Difficulty of getting supplies for lack of boats. Instructions for provisions for settlers arriving.
to Colvile. Regarding de Salis' trip to Red River and return; proposal as to cost.

to Colvile. Has transferred Lord Selkirk's property to Rupert's Land to Governor Bulger as instructed.Refers him to Halkett and Bulger regarding complaints against his management.Hopes to be allowed to retain the portion of McLean's lot he has improved. The Swiss gentlemen(de Hauser) who wintered in the Settlement and behaved extremely well is going home.
to Colvile. Justifying his conduct.Wishes to know name of his accuser. Report on the settlers.
to Colvile. Complaint against the agent. Gave flag and two medals to war parties and stopped them.Requests a new flag and medals. Endorsed.- A new flag and medals will be sent to him.
to A.Bulger.(French.) Will write his brother regarding his intention to conduct Swiss settlers to the Mississippi.
to Augustin Nolin. Protesting against his brother's conduct in enticing Swiss settlers away from Red River.

to Colvile. Reports his arrival and state of Settlement. Musk ox skins sent to England to ascertain its value. Mr.Tod going home and will give an account of the place. Wheat and barley crops excellent.
to Ellice. Lord Selkirk unwilling to sell his shares.
to F.Riser, Berne. Regarding his complaint Captain against de May. Advise as to what to take.
